categories.name: Pastabilities: A World Tour of Noodles

questions.clue: Originating from Italy, this long, thin noodle is often paired with meatballs and tomato sauce.
Made from wheat flour and eggs, this flat ribbon-like pasta is perfect for creamy Alfredo sauce.
A basic component of pho from Vietnam, these thin rice noodles are traditionally served in a hot beef soup.
This Japanese noodle, also known as 'buckwheat noodle,' is famous for being served both hot in broths and cold with dipping sauces.
Known for being 'heavy' in calories and protein, this unique noodle from Switzerland is named after a legendary Swiss hero.
This international weightlifting competition, established in 1891, is considered the sport's premier event. It's not to be confused with a pasta dish.
Often associated with pasta-eating Italians, this country's national sport organization is called the Federazione Italiana Pesistica.
In the 1920 Summer Olympics, this weightlifting legend, named after a popular pasta type, became the first American to win a gold medal in the sport.
Weightlifting was first included as a sport in these inaugural modern Olympic Games held in this year.
This competitive weightlifting event, named after the 'snatch,' was added along with the clean and jerk for a two-lift total in 1972.

categories.name: Beyond the Ball: Uncommon Sports and Games

questions.clue: In this aquatic motorsport, competitors race high-performance watercraft, often referred to as jet skis.
Enthusiasts of this sport take fitness routines to a new level by performing them on mini-trampolines.
Invented in Finland, this athletic event involves competitors hurling their cellphones for distance.
Requiring strength and balance, this adaptation of weightlifting uses raw spaghetti as the primary lifting object.
In this complex board game, players must strategically move pieces on a hexagonal grid inspired by bee behavior.

categories.name: Culinary Chemistry: The Science of Cooking

questions.clue: For $200: This kitchen staple, often used to boil pasta, reaches its boiling point at 100°C or 212°F at sea level.
For $400: Pasta is typically cooked until 'al dente', meaning 'to the tooth' in Italian; this refers to its texture when it’s firm but not hard, achieved due to the gelatinization of this starch.
For $600: This protein, found in wheat, gives pasta its elastic texture and is often developed through kneading the dough.
For $800: During pasta cooking, this process involves water moving into the pasta, making it swell and increase in weight.
For $1000: This scientific principle explains why cooked pasta releases starch when it's lifted with a fork, helping sauces adhere better.

categories.name: Classical Mythology: Tales of Gods and Heroes

questions.clue: He's known as the god of the sea and earthquakes, but don't look for him at your local gym's weight lifting rack.
This hero completed 12 labors, a set of tasks that didn't include cooking pasta but did involve capturing a fearsome boar.
He gave a famous pair of blacksmithing brothers some trouble after borrowing their flying sandals, much like weightlifters who forget to rerack weights.
Known for her weaving skills, this mortal boasted to Athena and got turned into a spider but didn't weave pasta farfalle.
This hunter, transformed into a constellation, was known for his strength but found no barbell heavier than his fate.

final.clue: This Italian city, known for its iconic pasta dishes, hosted the first modern Olympic Games that featured weightlifting as an event in 1920.
